statement:
The characteristic polynomial of a symplectic matrix is a reciprocal
polynomial.

Let $A$ be the symplectic matrix, and let
$p(\lambda) = \det(A-\lambda I)$ be its characteristic polynomial. We
wish to prove that $$p(\lambda) = \pm \lambda^n p(1/\lambda).$$ By
definition, $AJA^T=J$ where $J$ is the matrix
$$J=\left( \begin{array}{cc}
0 & I \\
-I & 0
\end{array} \right).$$ Since $A$ and $J$ are symplectic matrices, their
determinants are $1$, and $$\begin{aligned}
p(\lambda) &=& \det (AJ - \lambda J) \\
           &=&\det (AJ - \lambda AJA^T) \\
           &=&\det (-\lambda A) \det (J) \det (-\frac{1}{\lambda} J + JA^T) \\
           &=&\pm \lambda^n \det (A-\frac{1}{\lambda} I ).\end{aligned}$$
as claimed.
names: characteristic polynomial of a symplectic matrix is a reciprocal polynomial
